H0.text: Rods and cones are the light‑sensing photoreceptor cells in the retina, which receives light focused by the lens onto the back inside of the eye.

H1.text: Cones and tubes are the light‑sensing photoreceptor cells in the retina, which covers the back of the inside of the eye and receives light focused by the lens.

H2.text: Holes and cones are the light‑sensing photoreceptor cells in the retina, the layer that receives light focused by the lens onto the back of the inside of the eye.

H3.text: Tubes and rods are the light‑sensing photoreceptor cells in the retina, which covers the back inside of the eye where the lens focuses light.

A4.text: The two classic photoreceptor cells are rods and cones, each contributing information used by the visual system to form an image of the environment, sight.

A5.text: Rod and cone photoreceptors are found on the outermost layer of the retina; they both have the same basic structure.
